author: OptionsTrading.org
content: Defines calls and puts, strike prices, premiums, and expiry mechanics, then walks through beginner-friendly entry rules (low premium, hedged directional biases, and explicit max-loss brackets) plus how to pair options with index protection. The guide highlights why placing credit spreads or covered calls helps lock in yield without betting on volatility blowups and emphasizes building watchlists of liquid underlyings with measured gamma risk before deploying capital.

source_name: Investor Bulletin: Real Estate Investment Trusts (REITs)
author: SEC
content: Reiterates that REITs must invest 75% of assets in real estate, derive 75% of income from rents/finance, distribute at least 90% of taxable income, and limit insider ownership to retain tax flexibility. It contrasts equity, mortgage, and hybrid REITs (noting leverage differences) and compares public vs. non-traded REITs, offering risk-checks such as monitoring leverage, payout coverage, and liquidity exposure before committing dividend capital.

source_name: An Adaptive Multi-Agent Bitcoin Trading System
author: Aadi Singhi
content: AAI agents break the trading cycle into specialized roles (quant, sentiment, risk, reflections) and run verbal feedback loops so textual critiques steer future prompts instead of re-training weights. Bitcoin backtests show the sentiment agent turning sideways markets positive and the reflective critic reducing drawdowns, teaching the pipeline to incorporate multi-agent oversight, scenario tables, and guardrails (daily checklists plus weekly reflection) before executing trades.

author: Zhang Wei
content: Blends multi-timeframe trend encoders with high-frequency prediction heads tuned on order book + on-chain features. The architecture outputs sub-second buy/sell signals with statistical confidence intervals, adds pipeline reliability checks (latency, data quality) and guardrails for drawdowns, and demonstrates improved profit factors even after transaction cost overlays, matching the kind of backtest hygiene our trading desk demands.

source_name: International Banking and Nonbank Financial Intermediation
author: Claudia M. Buch & Linda S. Goldberg
chapter_or_section: Global liquidity and term premium implications
content: Charts how global liquidity injections flow through nonbank intermediaries and affect U.S. Treasury term premia, highlighting how leverage, regulation, and cross-border arbitrage keep long-end yields sensitive to capital controls. The paper says the Fed should monitor repo clearing, liquidity mismatches, and sovereign borrowing so the desk can translate those macro signals into defensive duration trades or hedged REIT positions when term premiums compress.
